Basically, lerp takes a value (start), subtracts it from another value (end), multiplies the sum by the speed (ie 0.1), and adds the first value to it.
For instance, say x is 100 and x2 is 200
lerp(x, x2, 0.1);
200 - 100 = 100, 100 * 0.1 = 10, 100 + 10 = 110
Now that x is 110,
200 - 110 = 90, 90 * 0.1 = 9, 110 + 9 = 119.
Since x increases, the difference decreases therefore slowing the increase of x. This forms the fast, then slow animation that you‚Äôre seeing.

Very nice paper! I'm impressed this is your first one, and I deeply enjoyed it. That being said, I do have a couple friendly critiques:

1. I am not the first user to state this, but make sure your news is, well, new! People enjoy news even more if your the first to tell them!

2. Make sure to avoid bias. In real newspapers, the only area for opinions is the editorial. This paper isn't nearly as biased as some, however the article does seem to be leaning towards bias.

That being said, the news was well written, and the extras section was beautiful. I especially enjoyed CoraL's story, and I think may submit a poem to this fine new paper!

Numbers are infinite both going up 1,2,3 and going down -1,-2,-3. No matter how many times Achilles halves the distance there will always be something left wich will be halved next time. Now, if the turtle stopped moving of course Achilles would close the gap eventualy.
This is a sweet explanation

This is similar to a theory a I think Greek physicist made. And is quite easy to solve, the gap is not halved, but reduced. After enough reduction, there is of course negative numbers. Let's say the gap is 3, the racer runs, now the gap is 2, he runs again, now the gap is 1, after another stride, the gap is 0. Any running he does past this will be a negative number in this example. -1, -2, -3 etc. etc. This is not a paradox, but an outdated misunderstanding of physics. Though despite this obvious hole in the paradox, it is still a really well done program.

I draw the wolf (with some masking to get the gradient fill) and take an image of it. I then take smaller images off it and store them in an array with some properties such as the original x and y coordinates, random x and y coordinates that each piece will start from, plus a random angle.

I then use `lerp` to bring all the pieces back to the original x, y coordinates.

How to play, as he/she said:

- In the settings menu, you can change the selected plant's level and see its stats.

- You can also select the level in settings.

- In the select plants page, click on a plant to add it to your line up. On some levels, plants are automatically selected.

- In game, collect suns (Yellow suns that appear) and use plants to defend your lawn from the incoming zombies (they come from the right).

- Some levels have tombstones. Tombstones act as obstacles that block the projectiles your plant produces. Use lobbing plants to throw projectiles over.

- Some levels have flowers. You lose if zombies trample the flowers. Flying zombies (balloon zombies) won't trample them if their balloon isn't popped.

I don‚Äôt think there is a bug, but it can be pretty hard. However, I (and others) have been able to destroy pirates. I made the hit radius for the pirates really small.

I used an array to represent the lines of text on the screen, where each item was a line of text. I also had some text broken by line that represented the text I wanted to display. To animate it, I added one character at a time from the target text to the line of text in the array at the index of the current line of text. When the length of the string in the array was too long, the code just increments the index of the current line of text. And when the current index is larger than the largest index in the array, I just delete the first line of text in the array and create a bee empty line of text at the end. 

That may or may not make any bit of sense. You‚Äôll probably want to look at my code if your still interested. The appropriate code is under the ‚ÄòDisplay‚Äô constructor.

The way I'm using .filter basically just replaces everything in the array with a function, but the function parameters and coordinates has to be the same as the array. This is a very basic example of using it, a little bit of tinkering with the code and you can figure it out :D
Ok, thanks :D
Ohh, I guess I got filter and forEach mixed up. Weird how it still works lol
That's probably because `.filter` executes everything within the function but only cares about the return value.

```
ohNoes.filter(stuff);
/*
Let output = [].
For each element in ohNoes:
  Let passedTest = stuff(element).
  _passedTest is undefined_
  If passedTest is true:
    Add element to output.
Return output.
_returns an empty array_
*/```As you can see, it still works. The function is called for each element, just like forEach.
Now I get it. Thanks :3

yeah same LittleWhinging

On the first line of code I define a function that houses all the project code. It's assigned to both a top variable and `*draw*`. It's assigned to a top variable to hold it in memory for later reference and is assigned to `*draw*` to delay the execution of it for one frame to avoid bugs that occur when event callback definitions are present. The function is first assigned to `*draw*` which is wrapped in parentheses to prevent EB from complaining about leaking `*draw*` when additionally assigning it to the top variable. Also, `*draw*` is not a variable like EB claims in the leaking error. It's a member/property of the output Processing instance.

Of course, you can't actually add infinitely many terms. What `1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 + ... = 1` really means is that as you add more and more terms, the sum _approaches_ 1. This means that if you choose any arbitrary distance from 1, _as small as you want_, eventually the sum will reach that distance.
To make it simpler, though, we just say the infinite sum equals 1.

TBF, I not sure why you mention the two programs you do, @IA. They were both based on reference images, which IMO, takes away 90% of the value of the graphic. This is not super high quality, but I would argue it is about equal to the two programs mentioned. The complex loops and arrays are brilliant!
@Timothy my code is actually highly inefficient. They also must have put a lot of effort into it (I took ~10 min on this).

Yes, @IA and @TP, I do realize the effort put into graphics (with or without reference images) but I just do not understand why they are idealized so highly by the KACP community. They are just a bunch of shapes and colors, very well placed shapes, often complex, but ultimately just that. I think them much better with masking, but still, I see user interactivity as a key factor in a program, which graphics inherently lack. Also they lack the the foundations of higher coding. No algorithms. No AI. Rarely OOP. Not User Interface.

*Graphical art is definitely a very important branch of computer science, but I believe KACP over emphasizes and glorifies it, making graphic design seem like the most important part of coding*. From my research, you can get an undergraduate degree in computer science without a single class in graphics (this obviously depends on the institution, and you would likely have to not choose the graphic design elective, but it still illustrates my point).

To say this is better than the two programs mentioned was to make a point, more than make an accurate statement.

I realize many kids here to do have futures in any form of Computer Science in mind. I also realize this is the view is unpopular, so I am not going make a program championing or anything. Just putting out ideas :D

@Timothy
I know, I think the fact that KACP is very graphic-oriented is mostly because Processing.js is meant for graphics. I also think graphics sometimes get overrated when there are other programs like complex AIs or original games.

# Clean Code
So you can write code. Do you ever expect to really use this skill? If so then you need to be abled to write clean, properly formatted code that anyone can pick-up and understand to a basic extent.

1. Spacing - when writing code betweena pair of braces or curly brackets ({}) you should ensure you have indented code properly. Generally either a tab character or 4 spaces is used.
```javascript
function exampleFunction() {
       // indented text
}
```
2. Operations - when using operations usually it is easier to read and better spacing out each value.
```javascript
var sum = variable1 + variable2 - variable3;
//     ^ ^         ^ ^         ^ ^ spaces
```
3. Variable/Parameter Naming - when creating parameters or variables it is good practice to use a descriptive name for the variable that describes what sort of information it might be storing. Their are also naming conventions that we generally follow to do with the formatting of variable/parameter names. One of the more popular naming conventions is Camel Casing. Camel Casing is when you capitalise every word except the first in a variable or parameter name.
```javascript
var fivePlusFive = 5 + 5;
```
Another common naming convention (more popular with Python I have found) is using underscores to seperate words.
```javascript
var five_plus_five = 5 + 5;
```
There are many more but if you choose to use one, make it standard in your program, don't switch naming conventions halfway along your program.

At the end of the day writing clean code is the only way to collaborate with other programmers.

So you will put in your color, let's say blue:
`fill(0, 0, 255);`
Then, in order to make a certain amount of transparency, you will put a fourth parameter into the fill call.
`fill(0, 0, 255, 100);`
You can play around with the fourth parameter until you get the amount of transparency you like. 
The lower the value of the fourth parameter, the more transparent it is.

`*sketchProc*` is a top variable that holds a function that houses all the project code so it can be called at a later point from within itself as a restart function. The function first assigned to `*draw*` is only called once. It's assigned to `*draw*` to delay it's execution one frame to prevent bugs that occur when event callback definitions are present.

Variables are fine to define in functions called by the main update loop. It is, however, wasteful to define objects in the main update loop that are only used during a single frame.

What happens when the gap becomes to small to see, mister greek philosopher, hmmmmmmmm??

*Reason*:

*distance > 0*`  `and`  `*distance / 2 = speed*
therefor`  `*speed < distance*`  `since`  `*speed + speed = distance*
therefor`  `*distance - speed > 0*

At some point in your race, you need speed to be equal to distance in order to make distance 0.

Eventually you will get a number so precise that it will not matter in the real world, and if you keep going you'll get round-off error, but you'll never actually reach 0.
